Deftux
Feature Stub

Recent:


Day 70: Typeform’s Signup (or Lack of)

What it is: Typeform lets you create a form (or even multiple forms) before you ever sign up for an account.

Why it’s good: When your user lands on your site, it’s pretty rare that their first thought is “Oh man, hope I have to fill out a sign in form!” They have goals to accomplish, but we usually throw a sign up form in their face as the first thing. We hope that they’ve gleaned enough value from our marketing material to take that first step big step of signing up.

As our technology has progressed, this imperative need to sign up for everything is evaporating, and yet you still see it on almost every site. Not only does Typeform allow you to just start making a form, (with some minor interruptions, grumble grumble) it even saves the form in a local session so if you leave and come back, your work is still there. They message this with a small button with a subtle flash in the top right, saying “Save Account.”

Duolingo has recently taken this approach too, and it is so wonderful because it allows demonstrated value. I don’t have to fork over my credentials to see if this product will be useful. I can jump in and try it out and then sign up when I see the value.


Day 69: Square Credit Card Entry

What it is: Square’s CashTag service has a very simple and condensed credit card form that wraps everything into a linear process while keeping you on a single screen.

Why it’s good: It’s worth noting that Square isn’t the only company that’s adopted this type of interface. I noticed a similar credit card entry when I was setting up Lyft.

This credit card entry does a lot to keep you contextualized in the form and to indicate where you are in the process. It auto selects the type of card when you enter the first few digits (Note: You should do this too) It keeps the last 4 of the card available, which is typically used as an identifier. There are even small hints, like flipping the card image over when it gets to the CVV.

This feels like one of the first examples of forms that are designed specifically and contextually for mobile. The way that they’ve condensed this form lets you get a high-level overview in an extremely small space - and walks you through it in a linear fashion. I haven’t seen any testing to see if users can get through this easily (which makes me a little shy to endorse it), but it is a good example of optimizing form experiences for small screens.


Day 68: Disqus’ Microcopy

What it is: On each section of their settings page, Disqus provides microcopy that conveys the context for each section in a single sentence.

Why it’s good: Microcopy serves as a bridge between me and a function. In each case here, it’s reasonably clear what each button does. The headlines give me an idea of what I can do in each section, which is important for scanning and general comprehension of the page.

What this microcopy does is more subtle: it gives me a why for each section. This can be impossibly difficult to do in a short headline. You need clarity and brevity so that the user can scan the page and find what they’re looking for. Consider the copy in the “Connected Accounts” section: “Connect your social media accounts for one-click login and to show off your online presence on your Disqus profile.” I now know what I will find in that section, and why it makes sense to enable the features.

Microcopy can’t make a bad interface good. When well-applied, though, it helps your user form a deeper understanding of your interface and your intentions.


Day 67: Waze’s Better Route

What it is: When Waze finds a faster route, it tells you “There’s a better route” and automatically selects it after a short period.

Why it’s good: The language for this is great. “There’s a better way” feels so soothing and helpful when you’re stuck in traffic. I love that it also knows to select the faster route if you don’t interact with it. By contrast, Google Maps defaults to cancelling the new option, which is perplexing—obviously I want the fastest route possible!

What I particularly like about this design is how Waze displays the info specifically for glancing. Each fragment of information in this modal window is reinforced in multiple ways. The timer is both a number and a circle graph. The time saved is shown in a minutes saved and a new arrival time. When you are designing for consumption while someone is driving, getting the idea quickly is paramount.


Day 66: Instagram Photo Suggestion

What it is: When you open Instagram with recent photos in your library, a small window slides up that suggests you post photos that you’ve taken that day.

Why it’s good: For contextual suggestion, this is obviously solid. If the user has recently taken a photo, it stands to reason that they might be coming to Instagram to post it.

What makes this suggestion particularly good is in its flexibility. There are more apps for photo taking and editing than I can possible think of. There are more avenues to share photos than are reasonable. Allowing users multiple ways to arrive at the desired behavior (and in a case like this, prompting the desired behavior) makes the application feel flexible and robust.
